author: @cupguin
text:
My grandmother was the one who changed my mind about myself.  She believed everyone deserved a roof over their head, that it was the basic fundamental truth of society that it was responsible for all of us.  Sure I agreed healthcare was a right and that less homelessness was better than more.  But somehow the idea that shelter should be a human right missed me.  Her unapologetic assertion and refusal to let me argue it changed me for the better.

It's too easy, even if you don't think poverty is a crime, to reframe the act of being homeless as a threat.  That it's understandable to dislike or shrug off the suffering of the homeless as inconvenient.  That you should meet people who believe that halfway rather than think of people who are homeless as being denied a human right.  That shift helped me but does leave me utterly lost when madness like this happens.  Starting from people shouldn't be murdered shouldn't be the starting point of conversations and yet clearly that's not universally acknowledged.

author: @hlm3690
text: THANK YOU!!! Until finding your video and article in Teen Vogue, I have been extremely disheartened to see Jordan's behavior on the subway framed as a "mental health crisis", even by those attempting to humanize him. Is it really so hard to imagine that he might have been expressing rightful and understandable anger at his life circumstances? Such anger is neither a sign of impending violence, nor necessarily a symptom of a "mental health crisis". Jordan was a human being attempting to survive in circumstances most people would agree were dehumanizing. How sad that his status in our society, his issues with mental health, all seem to exempt him from the freedom of having and expressing normal human emotions. Thank you for your commentary. RIP Jordan.

author: @FrozEnbyWolf150
text: I don't have nearly as much training as an ex-marine, but even I know that you don't put someone in a rear naked choke for 15 minutes unless your intent is to kill. It takes less than 10 seconds for that hold to render someone unconscious, at which point by definition they are no longer a threat. In my self-defense training I was taught, the moment someone stops being a threat is the moment you let up. Anything you do after that point is excessive force. Except this cannot even be called self-defense, because there is no evidence and no reporting indicating Neely was attacking anyone. If someone is using harsh words, then you use your own words to calm them down and deescalate the situation.

author: @cassiusdhami9215
text:
"Whenever the government provides opportunities in privileges for white people and rich people they call it ‚Äúsubsidized‚Äù when they do it for poor and Negro people they call it ‚Äúwelfare.‚Äù The fact that is that everybody in this country lives on welfare. Suburbia was built with federally subsidized credit. And highways that take our white brothers out to the suburbs were built with federally subsidized money to the tune of 90 percent. Everybody is on welfare in this country. The problem is that we all to often have socialism for the rich and rugged free enterprise capitalism for the poor. That‚Äôs the problem."
-Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

If he did he would've never joined the very place that goes around the globe killing Brown and Blk people. US Americans don't be surprised that the monsters you create to spread death and destruction bring it home, eventually.

replies.author: @cupguin
replies.text:
People use it because it works.  If it wasn't effective they'd have moved on to something else.

Society as a whole likes a stratification of criminals and those "most like us" are always treated better than outliers no matter their crime.  The crime of being mental ill while poor of worse than actual violent crimes by clean cut parents from the suburbs.  Hell they can get away with crimes that in theory we all agree are wrong the better looking they are.  Recognizing that fact about a society you are still succeeding in is tricky so it's nicer to think bad things happen to fundamentally bad people.  Or that if a bad thing happens society will care enough to do the right thing, not struggle over figuring out that the is.  But that's why it's always important to challenge why you feel the way you do and who you're agreeing with.

But none of these things happened... he was choked for 15 min by a man trained to kill. There is NOTHING a person can do to deserve this unless they are the killer in a slasher movie,

replies.author: @RVT203
replies.text:
@yaobikuni1349 I agree with you, that‚Äôs exactly what I want to understand. I initially saw a murder, saw that it was a black man murdered by a marine and my first thought was that he must have been justified. I see a murder and see it‚Äôs a white man murdered i immediately feel sympathy. Clearly im racist, even if it‚Äôs not in an outward way I know I don‚Äôt hate black people or any other race and yet I still have biases I didn‚Äôt even notice. 

I ignored the facts as stated because I saw a black man murdered by a marine and thought it must be justified. That‚Äôs what I almost fell for, and that‚Äôs not me trying to push that onto others, I simply saw someone else‚Äôs perspective on it and changed my mind. 

BUT NO SHIT! God a man was murdered and instead of thinking ‚Äúoh I hope his family gets justice‚Äù or ‚ÄúI hope he rests in peace‚Äù I thought ‚ÄúI wonder what he did‚Äù 
HOW FUCKED IS THAT?

author: @hughquigley5337
text: As someone who has had serious mental health struggles, I see Jordan Neely and think "that easily could have been me". The way people reacted to Jordan Neely's brutal, cold blooded murder in broad daylight will never cease to amaze me... the dehumanization of unhoused people is so prevalent its crazy. Him being a black person adds several layers to this that I'll never be able to fully understand as a white person, so I'm glad you made this video, Olayemi, because you added context I was unaware of (Bernie Goetz) and experience relatively few people have (being a public defender and activist). I'm also glad that the Majority Report covered this in the way that they did. Thank you for this video. RIP Jordan Neely... your society, city, state, country, and your fellow human beings failed you over and over and over again. These kinds of things happen to some of the most vulnerable people in our society on a daily basis, but aren't filmed or publicized. We need to build a world where this never happens to anyone ever again.

author: @alizardinyourroom1361
text: How homeless people in the US are treated is absolutely disgusting. This is unrelated but my city just recently held the superbowl and becuase of that they forced out a ton of homeless peoples encampments in order to "clean up downtown". My city has so many houseless people, we have "tent city" which is a large encampment for homeless people, which is constantly raided by the police. Its so frustrating becuase this doesnt have to be the case, that my city easily has the means to house these people, to make sure they get help they need, but instead just funnels more and more millions into the police. Its just so clear how fucked the priorities are, and how those priorities are actively against the lives of people.

author: @jakeschisler1417
text: I feel terrible that this happened, I hope Mr.Neely can rest in peace but I swear their were eyewitness accounts stating that he said "I'll hurt anyone on this train." I understand people's concern but it's shockingly accurate when you said how people were AFRAID not nervous or anxious. The real pity is how not a goddamn soul decided to intervine with Mr.Penny and help reorient his hold into a safer position for Mr. Neelys life while still detaining him because he appeared threatening. However, all of the facts and evidence that will be used in this trial will undoubtedly support Mr. Penny because of the eyewitness accounts and Mr. Penny claiming that he was in self defense, which he was (he just didnt have the courage to spare a life). I'm just horrified that Mr. Penny or anyone else didnt even try to talk to him first (please correct me if I'm wrong). THATS the tragedy here people are too quick to turn on their fellow man when they appear hostile in fear of thier own lives rather than trying to help even if they are unstable or appear dangerous (their are too many mindless sheep nowadays grazing on feed fed to them by electronic media). I also have been looking at other videos covering this situation and so many people are bringing up his criminal past even when it has nothing to do with the case, I have no idea why they would do that. I feel sick to my stomach about this whole situation bc at the end of the day, this is just going to polarize our country even more instead of bringing us together.

author: @MythyxArt
text:
Hasan reacted to you video and honestly I'm glad he did because your analysis is so incredible I had to come here myself and subscribe.
I've experienced a ton of racism in my life, but people write that off as a mere experience I had. Being a black person in America is scary. Once one of us does something wrong, it hurts our future and other black people around us who did nothing. I'm so glad you brought up that is deeply rooted in our institutions, policies, and even politics. Every time there's a black victim, people will do their best to look into your background to find dirt. It's disgusting, especially if said person was a victim of a racially motivated murder where their life doesn't even matter to the police.

To all my fellow black people and other minorities, I do hope you're able to find a community where you feel loved and accepted. It's hard to live, especially with racist people in office, but hopefully one day we can all live in peace without fear of being a victim of a hate crime. Rip to Jordan Neely üíú
